images.caption: Figure 1:An example of our repository-level code graph, where ‚ÄúPKG‚Äù, ‚ÄúFUNC‚Äù, and ‚ÄúT-FILE‚Äù represents ‚ÄúPACKAGE‚Äù, ‚ÄúFUNCTION‚Äù, and ‚ÄúTEXTFILE‚Äù respectively. In this graph, solid lines represent hierarchical dependencies (i.e., contains), while dashed lines represent reference dependencies (calls/imports/extends).

Figure 2:Architecture of CGM and its Graph RAG extension: Given an issue, (a) Rewriter extracts code entities and keywords from the issue (Extractor), and modifies the original issue into more detailed queries (Inferer).
Based on this, (b) Retriever locates relevant nodes from the corresponding code graph; then expands these nodes to a connected subgraph by including neighboring and upstream nodes.
(c) Reranker ranks retrieved results in two stages: File Name Rank and File Skeleton Rank, selecting the most relevant files for modification.
Finally, (d) Reader (CGM) takes the retrieved graph and selected files as input.
Each node‚Äôs code content is encoded by an Encoder‚Ñ∞‚Ñ∞{\mathcal{E}}caligraphic_E, producing a node token via the Adapterùíúùíú{\mathcal{A}}caligraphic_A.
Node tokens are then concatenated with text tokens in the prompt before entering the LLM decoderùíüùíü{\mathcal{D}}caligraphic_D, where the adjacency matrix replaces its original attention mask.
